poem:
False Hopes  

Industrial whispers, promises in the air,  
A machine idles, waiting, waiting—  
Decisive, they say—a word like thin mist,  
cloaking uncertainty.  

Beneath the gleam of polished steel,  
jobs teeter and hum in silent factories,  
while lives hang serrated on the edge—  
and distant winds carry voices of doubt.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The government has raised false hopes at Jaguar Land Rover. There has been no ‘decisive action’ | Nils Pratley “Following our decisive action, this loan guarantee will help support the supply chain and protect skilled jobs in the West Midlands, Merseyside and throughout the UK,” Peter Kyle, the business secretary, claimed at the weekend. Decisive? Really? That is not how life looks to many on the ground in the UK car industry. Some smaller suppliers". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
